ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to approach an organic synthesis problem and how to choose the reagents for the desired product
I learned a lot about organic chemistry, including about enolate reactivity, chiral auxiliaries, the aldol reaction, umpolungs, and other topics.

After only taking sophomore organic chemistry and doing limited synthesis in research, I learned a lot about how to approach and troubleshoot syntheses. I would feel more comfortable rotating in a synthetic lab after taking this course.  I feel I developed much better intuition about how reactions will go given the starting materials and reagents. I became more comfortable designing syntheses.
I learned about a range of valuable enantioselective/diastereoselective methods to synthesize organic molecules of interst.

This course taught me more aspects of synthetic organic chemistry than any traditional organic chemistry class, focusing heavily on reaction conditions and range/scope grounded to applications and actual uses beyond just problem sets and exams. We learned and compared many techniques based on literature data and lab experience.
Advanced organic synthesis methods
I learned new methods in preparing carboxylic acids, esters, and aldehydes using chiral auxiliaries and stereoselective methods.
Insights into synthetic chemistry, major trends, new ways of thinking in high level but applicable synthetic problems
General in depth understanding of the covered topics. How to solveproblems.

Basic but commonly used organic chemistry techniques in industry, and how they were developed. Basic mechanisms for alkylation, Aldols, and carbonyl additions. Application of said techniques to theoretical multi step synthesis.
You get to learn a lot of commonly used synthetic methods re: enolates and asymmetric alkylations, etc. Very useful and very well taught!

Amazing introduction to the graduate courses in the Chemistry department after taking the year-long organic chemistry sequence. Having read some literature and familiarity with basics of protecting groups, common oxidants and reductants, a sprinkling of named reactions is helpful but not at all necessary. If you're interested at all by natural products, methodology, or even medicinal chemistry, this course is a must.
I learned the ins and outs of enolate chemistry, and how to apply it in many different fashions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - clear notes, good examples
The lectures were very informative, the instructions for assignments were clear, and we got helpful feedback on assignments quickly.

Strengths: very well taught, approachable for students without a strong synthetic background, introduced lots of current and relevant synthetic methods, I always felt that the reasoning and significance of reactions were emphasized

Weaknesses: n/a, this is the best chemistry course I have ever taken
Extremely well organized -- notes on board very clear. Professor did a great job explaining concepts during class. Office hours very helpful. Assignments very fair and reflective of course material.

The course is entirely research-focused, with connections to industrial applications. Although the topics covered were few, the depth and specificity of the covered reactions will be extremely helpful and insightful for anyone interested in a career in chemistry. I only wish that this class was longer and that there was more time to cover more content.
The course is fast-paced but very interesting in regards to content
It would be great to have the notes uploaded to canvas, as sometimes I miss something written on the board.

Professor Ellman is a wonderful lecturer and takes the time to make himself available to all students. He is clearly very knowledgeable and takes care to explain concepts thoroughly and at a level that students can comprehend.
Instructor creates great environment. Easy to ask questions and get good answers. Improvements: none!!
Great class! The biggest strength is the organization. Each class had a to of content, but the problems sets really help lock everything in and the exam felt very fair.

Strengths: Prof. Ellman is a great lecturer with a broad knowledge of the field and did a great job of explaining the concepts in a concise manner. The PSETS and the exam were also very straight-forward which was a nice bonus.
Weaknesses: None that I can think of!
Very lecture focused. The content is there to succeed. I liked the deep dive into a small number of reactions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
Yes, if you are interested in organic chemistry. The class is very interesting but the material is quite dense.

Absolutely, if you have any interest in organic chemistry, this class is helpful. It will give you lots of detailed information about specific reactions, but general principles (importance of stereoselectivity, thermodynamic vs. kinetic conditions, C-C bond formation, etc.) can be carried over to other reactions.
Yes, very worthwhile for students interested in organic synthesis and wanting to learn about new chemical transformations beyond undergraduate organic chemistry 1 and 2.

I would highly recommend this course to both students interested in graduate school as well as anyone with an interest in the field of chemistry. The reactions learned as well as the broader knowledge of chemistry gained through this class are invaluable and incomparable, especially given that Professor Ellman is a phenomenal lecturer who has extensive experience in the topics he covers.
Yes, Dr. Ellman was a great instructor and I learned cool new synthesis techniques!
Yes, especially those interested in organic cynthesis.

Yes! Natural extension off undergraduate organic chemistry and it is super valuable content, even if you're not planning to go into organic chemistry. I appreciated the way Professor Ellman got us to think about the synthetic problems and challenged us in a way that felt encouraging.
Yes, you learn a lot and it is fun. Problemsets well adjusted to course content.
Yes! Great chem elective where you also get to meet a great prof. And many Grady students!

Absolutely! It's a great way to get further knowledge of common synthetic techniques and gives you a good sense on how to approach some common retrosynthetic problems. I recommend getting a study group with some friends.
Absolutely.
Yes, there is no course better for learning about enolate chemistry!
